title: How to Get Cactus Needles Out of Skin, Clothes, & Hair

steps.title: Take out standard cactus needles using tweezers.
steps.content: Take out standard cactus needles using tweezers. If you can see a cactus needle clearly, grip the end of it with a pair of sterilized tweezers and pull it out. To avoid snapping the needle, do your best to remove it in a single, straight motion. [1] X Research source If the needle gets buried deep under your skin, locate the tip furthest away from the entry wound and gently push it out. Sterilize your tweezers with rubbing alcohol or antibacterial soap. [2] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you’re having trouble seeing the needles, hold your skin under a bright light or look through a magnifying glass.

steps.title: Remove tiny cactus needles with duct tape.
steps.content: Remove tiny cactus needles with duct tape. If multiple, tiny cactus spines are stuck in your skin (such as glochids), place a piece of duct tape or packing tape over the needles. Lightly press it into your skin and then rip the tape off. This gets rid of large amounts of cactus spines at once. [3] X Research source Repeat the process with fresh tape until all of the cactus needles are gone.

steps.title: Pull out stubborn cactus hairs with white glue or rubber cement.
steps.content: Pull out stubborn cactus hairs with white glue or rubber cement. Using a cotton swab, tongue depressor, or other small applicator, apply a large amount of white glue (like Elmer’s ) or rubber cement to the pierced area. Let the glue or cement dry, then pull the edges of the adhesive up slowly and carefully. Repeat the process multiple times to remove as many needles as possible. [4] X Research source Your drying time will vary based on which brand of glue or rubber cement you use. You may feel some slight pain as the adhesive dries. To combat this, take a standard dose of an over-the-counter painkiller, like acetaminophen. Another option is to apply hair removal wax over the cactus spines. Smooth on the wax, press on a cloth strip, and then rip off the wax. [5] X Trustworthy Source HealthyChildren.org Health information from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Go to source

steps.title: Brush off glochids using a nylon stocking.
steps.content: Brush off glochids using a nylon stocking . Glochids are thin, hairlike cactus needles that are shorter and less rigid than regular cactus spines. To remove them, put on protective gardening gloves and wad up a pair of nylon pantyhose. Then, rub the hose against the affected area to pull out the glochids. [6] X Research source When dealing with glochids, nylon hose provides all the adhesive power of duct tape without causing any unwanted skin irritation.

steps.title: Dress your wound after getting the needles out.
steps.content: Dress your wound after getting the needles out. After removing the cactus needles from your skin, clean the pierced area with fresh water and soap for 5 to 10 minutes. Once you’ve removed as much dirt and debris as you can, apply antibiotic cream to the wound and cover the entire affected area with gauze wrap or a bandage. [7] X Research source For safety, wash your hands with antibacterial soap before cleaning the wound. If you see any cactus hairs in the wound site, pick them out using tweezers sterilized with rubbing alcohol or antibacterial soap. [8] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Until the wound heals, change your bandage at least once a day or whenever it becomes dirty or wet.

steps.title: Seek medical help if you can’t remove the needles.
steps.content: Seek medical help if you can’t remove the needles. Visit a doctor if you can’t get cactus needles out of your arms, legs, or any other non-sensitive areas of your body. If you get cactus needles stuck in your neck, throat, or any other sensitive spots that you can’t easily remove them from, head to the emergency room as soon as possible. [9] X Trustworthy Source HealthyChildren.org Health information from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Go to source Leaving cactus needles in your skin for a long period of time can lead to infections.

steps.title: Remove small cactus needles using duct tape.
steps.content: Remove small cactus needles using duct tape. Small cactus hairs like to bury themselves in fabric, making them incredibly difficult to remove. However, you can usually get a large portion of them out using duct tape or a similarly strong adhesive. To do so, cover the affected area with a strip of tape, then rip the tape off. Repeat this multiple times for the best results. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Pull out large cactus needles with a comb.
steps.content: Pull out large cactus needles with a comb. Unlike small needles, large cactus spines and ball-like hitchhikers are easy to remove from clothing. To do so, grab a fine-toothed comb and place it just above the needles. Then, run the comb down through the needles to brush them off. [11] X Trustworthy Source US National Park Service Agency responsible for the maintenance and promotion of national parks and monuments Go to source Once you’ve removed most of the needles, get rid of any stragglers using duct tape or a pair of tweezers. When combing, make sure to keep your hand as far away from the needles as possible.

steps.title: Clean your clothes in a washing machine to remove leftover needles.
steps.content: Clean your clothes in a washing machine to remove leftover needles. Once you’ve removed as many needles as you can, place your clothing items in a washing machine and run them through a normal cleaning cycle. Doing so helps remove any small hairs you couldn’t get out by hand. [12] X Research source Do not wash your affected clothes with other garments, otherwise you may simply move the cactus needles from 1 item to another.

steps.title: Pull out large needles with a pair of tweezers.
steps.content: Pull out large needles with a pair of tweezers. If large, clearly visible cactus spines get tangled up in your hair, grab them with a pair of tweezers and pull them out. These needles may be accompanied by small, hard-to-see cactus hairs, so put on gardening gloves to keep your hands safe. [13] X Research source If any of the cactus spines pierced your scalp, ask a friend or family member to check for major signs of damage. If they notice any, visit a doctor immediately.

steps.title: Remove small and stuck needles with a comb.
steps.content: Remove small and stuck needles with a comb. To keep your hands safe, put on a pair of gardening gloves. Then, grab a fine-toothed comb and run it through the affected areas of your hair. This will help you remove thin, difficult-to-see cactus hairs, as well as any stubborn hitchhikers that got tangled up in your locks. [14] X Research source If you’re having a difficult time, soak your hair in warm water for about 10 minutes. This helps loosen everything up and makes the cactus needles easier to remove.

steps.title: Cut your hair if you can’t remove the needles.
steps.content: Cut your hair if you can’t remove the needles. If you can’t seem to get the cactus needles out of your hair, you may need to cut the affected areas off with scissors or shave them down using a razor. Though you might feel tempted to simply leave the needles in, doing so can lead to incredible amounts of discomfort and, if the needles reach your scalp, serious infections. [15] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source
